Towards a more complete sample of binary central stars of
planetary nebulae with
Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge, Madingley Road, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK

Many if not most planetary nebulae (PNe) are now thought to be the outcome of binary evolutionary scenarios. However
only a few percent of PNe in the Milky Way are known to host binary systems. The high precision repeated observing and long time
baseline of
make it well suited to detect new close binaries through photometric variability.
We aim to ﬁnd new close binary central stars of PNe (CSPNe) using data from the
signiﬁcant sample of post common envelope, close binary CSPNe.

sources do not have published epoch photometry, we use the uncertainty in the mean photome-
try as a proxy for determining the variability of our CSPN sample in the second

data release. We derive a quantity that expresses
the signiﬁcance of the variability, and consider what is necessary to build a clean sample of genuine variable sources.

Our selection recovers a large fraction of the known close binary CSPN population, while other CSPNe lying in the same
region of the parameter space likely represent low-hanging fruit for ground-based conﬁrmatory followup observations.

photometry for four of the newly identiﬁed variable sources conﬁrms that the variability is genuine and consistent with binarity.
binaries: close – planetary nebulae: general – Methods: statistical

Planetary Nebulae (PNe) are the product of low and interme-
diate mass stars that underwent extensive mass loss during the
Asymptotic Giant Branch (AGB) phase. The textbook version of
the story is that PNe are the swan song of stars between 1 and 8
solar masses that are nearing the ends of their lives. Such stars
shed their outer layers, growing brighter and hotter and ionising
the newly formed nebula before ultimately cooling and fading
into white dwarfs. While this explanation may indeed hold for
some PNe, it has become increasingly clear in recent decades
that many of these stars do not die alone: a signiﬁcant fraction, if
not a majority, of PNe are produced by systems that have under-
gone binary interactions (Miszalski et al. 2009a; Bo

n & Jones
2019). Particularly compelling evidence comes from the diverse
range of morphologies observed in PNe (Balick & Frank 2002),
the most dramatic of which are thought to come from the pres-
ence of a close binary companion (Miszalski et al. 2009b; Jones
& Bo

n 2017). Some authors have even suggested that binarity
might be a requirement for the formation of a PN, which would
resolve the tension between population synthesis models and the
unexpectedly low number of PNe observed in the Milky Way
(Moe & De Marco 2006).

Close binary central stars of PNe are not only relevant for the
study of PNe: they also place important constraints on common-
envelope (CE) theory (Iben & Livio 1993; Yungelson et al.
1993), a poorly understood evolutionary phase that is critical
for the formation of a wide variety of astrophysical phenomena,

including cataclysmic variables, low-mass x-ray binaries, type
Ia supernovae, mergers, and gravitational wave sources (Jones
2020). A statistically signiﬁcant sample of close binary systems
is crucial for observationally constraining the orbital period dis-
tribution, which, in turn, is an important probe of the CE e

Such a sample is lacking: the identiﬁcation of close binary
central stars has been a painstaking process, with only 15 such
systems revealed in the 30 or so years following the discovery
of the ﬁrst example (see Chapter 3 of Bo

n & Jones 2019, for
a historical overview) and the current total standing around 70.
Binarity manifests itself in various ways. Widely separated pairs
can be detected visibly, particularly from space (Ciardullo et al.
1999; Benetti et al. 2003; Liebert et al. 2013), and bright but
close companions produce blended spectra (which can some-
times be conﬁrmed by long-term, high-resolution radial velocity
monitoring; Jones et al. 2017). Radial velocity variations are the
most conclusive evidence but are often di

cult to measure due
to contamination from bright nebula lines and spurious variabil-
ity stemming from post-AGB winds (De Marco et al. 2004). The
most dramatic photometric variability comes from eclipses (re-
quiring a lucky alignment of the orbital plane, e.g.; Jones et al.
2019) and

or the irradiation of a cool companion (e.g.; Munday
et al. 2020). In very close systems, tidal distortion can result

in the presence of ellipsoidal modulation in the observed light
curve (e.g.; Santander-García et al. 2015). Detection of photo-
metric variations is also subverted by the presence of a bright
nebula and aggravated by variable seeing conditions for ground-

based monitoring (Jones et al. 2015). Space-based photometric
monitoring has shown promising results, with variability in PN
central stars having recently been identiﬁed in Kepler

K2 (De
Marco et al. 2015; Jacoby et al. 2020) and TESS (Aller et al.
2020), though the high sensitivity of these missions is somewhat
o

set by the low spatial resolution, which dilutes the signal, par-
ticularly in the presence of nearby stars or bright nebulosity.

mission (Gaia Collabo-
ration et al. 2016) o

ers great promise as it tracks not only posi-
tional but also photometric variations, and does so for the whole
sky, including most known PN central stars (Chornay & Walton
2020).

ers high spatial resolution and long time base-
lines at the cost of irregular sampling and a long wait for the
availability of full epoch photometry for all sources. This paper
illustrates the potential of the

mission for the discovery and
characterisation of new binary PN central stars.

’s mission, any given source is observed
many times. The pattern of the observations is dictated by

’s
scanning law (Gaia Collaboration et al. 2016), and the frequency
at which a given source is observed depends on its position in the
sky. The scanning law is such that a source should be observed at
least six separate times over the course of a year, though due to

’s two telescopes and its rate of rotation, each of those so-
called visibility periods generally has at least two observations
of the source, separated by a few hours (Eyer et al. 2017).
A crossing of a source across

’s focal plane is called a
ﬁeld-of-view (FoV) transit. During an FoV transit a source’s ﬂux
is measured multiple times across di
has three passbands: the main, wide

band there
are typically eight or nine CCD transits per FoV transit; in

’s intermediate data releases include
only the mean photometry in each band, that is, the mean ﬂux

. In the calculation of these quantities in-
dividual CCD ﬂux measurements are weighted by their nominal
precisions (Eq. 6 and Eq. 7 in Carrasco et al. 2016). However the
uncertainty in the mean is based on the observed measurement
scatter, so it may not match that expected from the uncertain-
ties of the individual ﬂuxes. In particular, if a source is variable,
this will manifest as increased scatter and a higher uncertainty.
If variability is the dominant source of the scatter, the amplitude
of that variability can be derived from the published uncertainty.
The uncertainty in the mean ﬂux of a source published in the

catalogue is the weighted standard deviation of the individ-
ual ﬂux measurements divided by the square root of the number
of CCD transits

umn). The weights are not published, but if we assume that the
weights are equal, we can recover the standard deviation of the

An even more convenient relation comes from assuming that
the variation is sinusoidal, as it often approximately is for close
binary systems. In that case,

The intrinsic measurement uncertainty varies signiﬁcantly with

magnitude, increasing for fainter sources due to photon statis-
tics as well as including noticeable features at other magnitudes
related to di

erences in data acquisition and calibration. It is im-
portant to ascertain whether the apparent variability that we ob-
tain is actually signiﬁcant. If we had the per-FoV transit uncer-
tainties, we could determine an excess noise statistic analogous
to the unit weight error for astrometric measurements. However,
we do not have those, and, moreover, the errors are heteroscedas-
tic, depending not only on source colour and magnitude, but
varying temporally and spatially due to factors such as straylight
conditions and sky background. Nonetheless the considerations
are broadly similar to those discussed in Lindegren (2018) in
the context of

’s re-normalised unit-weight error (RUWE)
statistic for astrometry.

certainties in each bin. Interpolating between these values yields

We apply our methodology to the CSPN catalogue of Chornay

& Walton (2020). That catalogue was generated using an au-
tomated method to match CSPNe with sources in

data
release 2 (DR2), and includes a reliability parameter (between
0 and 1) that indicates the certainty of the match. We expect
that

’s early data release 3 (EDR3) will not signiﬁcantly
change the results; in particular it does not contain any new
epoch photometry or variability analysis that can be used to val-
idate our assumptions, and any new detections will be for faint
sources where only the most extreme variability would be de-
tectable. We join our catalogue with a compilation of known and
suspected binary CSPNe from literature,

excluding one extra-
galactic PN and six objects identiﬁed as non-PNe in the Hong

(HASH) PN catalogue of Parker et al.
(2016), while adding PHR J1040-5417 (Hillwig et al. 2017).

Fig. 1 shows the variability amplitude plotted against

magnitude for the sources in our sample, colour-coded by binary
type. The sample has been ﬁltered by CSPN match certainty (re-

; see Sect. 3.2
for motivation) giving 683 objects in total (see Table 1).

Non-variable binaries (blue) include those with composite
spectra and those detected (or hypothesised) based on infrared
excess. Visual binaries (green) have typically been discovered
through high resolution

Space Telescope imagery (and
appear blended in ground-based imagery), but do not have mea-
sured radial velocity or photometric variation. Long period bi-
naries (orange) have composite spectra and measured periods
(using radial velocity variations) on the order of years. Some
exhibit shorter timescale variability due to rotation. Short period
or close binaries (red) generally exhibit the greatest photometric
variability. These have typical periods less than a day, with only
a few between 2 and 20 days. Half-ﬁlled red circles are possible
short period binaries whose nature is still uncertain: the recent
discoveries in TESS from Aller et al. (2020), objects designated
as in need of further study by Miszalski et al. (2011), and Pa 5
from Kepler (De Marco et al. 2015). A few short period binaries
had also been noted previously as visual binaries or composite
spectra; in these cases the short period binarity takes precedence.
The remainder of the sample (objects of unknown binarity) are

the ﬂux maximum, which will contribute to a poor ﬁt and a

, astro-
metric issues can also be caused by the two components of a

binary being detected separately and later incorrectly merged
into a single source (Antoja et al. 2018), in which case the

ﬂag will be set. Such merging is also
likely to manifest as spurious photometric variability if the com-
ponents have di

erent magnitudes. Partially resolved binary sys-
tems could also cause issues for

line spread func-

position measurements.

The top panel of Fig. 3 shows RUWE versus the variabil-

in Fig. 1. All known extended short period binary systems (red
points) have RUWE

4, 1.4 be-

for well-behaved sources sug-
gested by Lindegren (2018). Such values suggest that the pho-

issues. Several visual binaries (green) have signiﬁcant variabil-
ity and high RUWE values. These pairs are typically separated
by around 0.3
, a separation at which they can be resolved by

but then are merged into a single source. This merging is
likely responsible for both the high photometric scatter and poor
astrometric ﬁt.

Several visual binaries also have relatively high photomet-
ric excess factors (middle panel of Fig. 3), as the window used
photometry captures both members of the pair.

However the distinction between well-behaved sources and not
is less clear than for RUWE, as other features such as crowded
ﬁelds and bright nebulae can also contaminate the

photometry without necessarily introducing spurious variability
in the

band. The suggested excess factor threshold from Evans
et al. (2018) for an object with

0 is shown for ref-
erence, though it is too conservative for our application and we
do not use any cut based on excess factor.

The lower panel of Fig. 3 shows the relation between vari-
ability signiﬁcance and nebula radius. There is a notable ex-
cess of high variability objects at smaller radii. This is not sur-

prising, as these nebulae tend be brighter, and thus introduce
an additional source of sky background. Compact nebulae can
also cause the sorts of astrometric issues described previously.
Known binaries at smaller radii do exhibit signiﬁcant variability,

In Fig. 2 we further break down known close binary systems
by the type of variability. The criteria for inclusion are loosened
relative to Fig. 1 in order to increase the sample size (see counts
in Table 1). The greatest variability is evident in irradiated bina-
ries. Ellipsoidal modulation generally produces a smaller e

ect,
while most binaries that have been detected solely through ra-
dial velocity variation (spectroscopic binaries, shown as upward
pointing triangles) have no signiﬁcant photometric variability in

, being e.g. double degenerate systems such as Fg 1 (Bof-
ﬁn et al. 2012) and NGC 2392 (Miszalski et al. 2019). Of the
systems with low

variability, only AMU 1 has been pre-
viously identiﬁed as a photometric variable, with Kepler pho-
tometry revealing low-amplitude modulation due to relativistic
Doppler boosting (De Marco et al. 2015).
These ﬁgures demonstrate the power of the scatter in the

mean photometry. Comparing Fig. 1 and Fig. 2 we can see
that all short period binaries in the sample of extended PN with
CSPNe brighter than

19 that have ground-based detections
of photometric variability (i.e. that are not solely spectroscopic
binaries) also have signiﬁcant variability in

, with variabil-

least 0.1 mag in the
band (around the limit of what is de-
tectable from the ground). The only conﬁdently known extended

19, MPA J1759-3007, is visibly sepa-
rated from the trend, but has a low number of FoV transits and
narrowly fails to meet the
Without time series photometry it is di

cult to distinguish be-
tween genuine variability (possibly related to binarity) and un-
usually high photometric scatter. Being bright, extended objects,
PNe are particularly likely to cause problems for

. In this
section we consider possible sources of spurious variability.

Markers outlined in black in Fig. 1 are objects that have signiﬁ-
cant

cri-
teria common to all objects in the extended sample. We choose
the criteria, in particular the threshold

8, as a balance be-
tween precision and recall, with the aim of selecting known short
period binaries (red points in Fig. 3). The 92 objects meeting
these criteria represent 13% of that sample overall, but include
27 short period binaries (77% of those in the sample), as well
as 4 long period binaries exhibiting shorter timescale variability,
and 1 visual binary with a borderline RUWE value.

This leaves 58 objects that are not previously known or sus-
pected binaries but exhibit signiﬁcant variability in

. Of
them, 43 have log variability amplitude

5, suggestive of
a level of variability that, if real, should be recoverable from
ground-based followup. Conﬁrming and measuring the periods
of these systems, even at a moderate success rate, would dramat-
ically increase the sample of known binary CSPNe. The list of
these objects is given in Table A.1.

Such a wealth of previously undiscovered binaries is not un-
expected. An unbiased ground-based survey, OGLE-III, previ-
ously found a close binary fraction of 12–21% (Miszalski et al.

18) contains 318 PNe. Of these 9–11% are known short period

trying to recreate the limits of the OGLE survey) we would ﬁnd
a binary fraction of 18%, consistent with the range from OGLE.

The estimate depends on the particular thresholds chosen, and
misses spectroscopic binaries, but this consistency supports the
hypothesis that many of the newly discovered variables are in-
deed binaries.

One strong indicator of PN central star binarity is a high abun-
dance discrepancy factor (ADF; Wesson et al. 2018). This is the
ratio of abundances of the same species derived from recombi-
nation lines of a photoionised nebula to those derived from col-
lisionally excited lines. It has a median value of 2.6 for PNe.
Extreme values of the ADF (ADF

5) in PNe are associated
with close binary central stars with a period of the order of a day
or less. Showing that some of the variables in our sample exhibit
such extreme ADFs would strengthen the link.

We join our catalogue with a compilation of literature ADF
values,

0.5 but relax the angu-
lar size cut to include more compact PNe (radii

). The 50
objects that passed these cuts (out of the 123 Galactic PNe with
literature ADFs) are shown in Fig. 4. There are 21 PNe exhibit-
ing extreme ADFs, of which 12 are already known or suspected
to harbour close binaries.

8 lines without black outlines have high RUWE values; the
bias of the ADF sample towards compact, bright PNe, which are
more amenable to spectroscopy, likely contributes to the larger
proportion of astrometric issues relative to the sample in Fig. 1.
These issues could in turn be responsible for some of the ob-
served photometric scatter (as it seems to be for some sources in
the top panel of Fig. 3), though the observed scatter still serves
as an upper bound.

With that in mind, it is reassuring that, of the extreme ADF
sample, only NGC 40 does not show at least some variability.
Along with NGC 40, NGC 2022 and M 1-42 have so far eluded

ground-based detections of periodic variability. From Fig. 4 we
can see that variation in the CSPN of NGC 2022 seems likely
to be genuine (

1.4) but on the threshold of
ground-based detectability, while for M 1-42 with high variabil-
ity signiﬁcance

3.0, the situation is less
clear. Of the remaining extreme ADF objects, four have signiﬁ-
cant variability and low RUWE (though most of their amplitudes
are again likely to be di

cult to detect from the ground), while
NGC 2440 has an extreme RUWE value that makes its apparent
variability inconclusive, and H 1-41 has a moderate variability
signiﬁcance of

8, which may be improved in the future
with more observations.

data alone, we can conclude that NGC
40 is unlikely to have strong photometric variability (though that
of course does not preclude it from being a binary), but only state
for other extreme ADF objects that their photometric scatters
are consistent with variability caused by binarity. Light curves
are needed to ascertain whether there is a periodic component to
the scatter of these objects, and whether the period matches the
expectation from Wesson et al. (2018), who found that extreme-
ADF PNe have central stars with periods of less than 1.15 days.

DR2 is limited
to about 550 000 sources that were classiﬁed as

’s own analysis (Holl et al. 2018). Epoch photom-
etry (ﬂux measurements for a source at each FoV transit)
is published for all of these sources, as well as a table
(

) of summary statistics de-
rived from that photometry. Around 3000 sources exhibiting
short timescale variability additionally have frequency informa-
tion published in the

However completeness is low: only four of the known short
period binary CSPNe are classiﬁed as

, despite many
more being known to exhibit strong photometric variability, and
only two of them have frequencies recovered by

. Addition-
ally four other sources are classiﬁed as

that are not
previously known binaries. All eight of these

sources
were also identiﬁed in our selection as signiﬁcantly variable
based on their ﬂux uncertainties. Though they represent only a
fraction of such sources, their epoch photometry o

ers a window
through which to probe the nature of their variability, as well as
the assumptions that went into our analysis.

of VanderPlas & Ivezi´c 2015) on the eight

Table 2 contains the parameters of the best ﬁts. Derived phase-

folded light curves and residuals are shown in Fig. 5 for known
binaries and Fig. 6 for new candidates. All eight

sources have good ﬁts, and three out of the four derived periods
for known binary systems also match literature values.

One exception is Abell 41, where our derived period is half
that in literature (Jones et al. 2010). The variability of Abell 41 is
believed to be due to ellipsoidal modulation and partial eclipses,
so it has two minima per orbit, and the shape of its folded light
curve is di

erent from the others in the sample and less well
described by a sinusoid. We have plotted the folded light curve
for Abell 41 at double our derived period to reﬂect this, though
the di
erence e.g. in the depths of the minima is di
’s sparse sampling (cf. Fig. 2 of Bruch et al. 2001).

The known irradiated binary PHR J1040-5417 has deep pri-
mary eclipses (Hillwig et al. 2017) that are not visible in the
epoch photometry; instead there is a gap at the light curve min-
imum. The eclipse is deep enough that it would be close to the
detection limit of
scanning law shows that this gap also exists in the sampling.

The four newly discovered variable CSPNe are those of Cr
1, KTC 1, Kn 124, and Pa 48. All of these PNe are relatively re-
cent discoveries; only Cr 1 and KTC 1 (Jacoby et al. 2010) have
spectroscopic conﬁrmation of their PN status. Kn 124 and Pa
48 (Kronberger et al. 2016) do not and are only listed as possible

and likely PNe in the HASH PN catalogue. None have published
narrowband imagery or morphological information.

band light curves of these newly discovered variables
are well described by sinusoidal ﬁts. The shape, amplitude, and
periods of the curves are consistent with irradiation e

ects, in
which one side of a cool companion is heated by the CSPN and
contributes to the ﬂux of the system most when it is directly be-
hind the CSPN; i.e. the hot side is facing the observer. With irra-
diation e

ects there is one ﬂux maximum per orbit, so the period
of the variation is the period of the binary system. None of the
systems appear to be eclipsing, and the uncertainty in
is too large to measure any colour e

ects. We conclude that
they are likely binaries, though constraining the parameters of
the systems is not possible without additional data and is beyond
the scope of this work.

for by adding a second higher-frequency term to its ﬁt. The am-
plitude of the remaining variability (derived from the weighted
variance of the residuals of the sinusoidal ﬁts) is shown in Fig. 7.
The signiﬁcance of most of the residuals is low. The low residual
variability of Cr 1 and KTC 1 compared to typical CSPNe is due
to their relatively red central stars, which have a lower intrinsic
measurement uncertainty.

shows tremendous promise for the study of CSPNe.
Though

’s own variability processing is quite limited, com-
bining the scatter in the photometry with the notion of variabil-
ity signiﬁcance introduced in this work allows us to retrieve
a large fraction of the binary systems that have been discov-
ered from painstaking ground-based observations over the past
decades. The newly discovered likely variables o

er a promising
set of targets for ground-based photometric followups, building
towards a statistically signiﬁcant sample of post-AGB, post-CE
stars. Many of their nebulae have chemistry or morphology typ-
ically associated with binarity. Selecting targets on variability,
rather than expectations of binarity based on other features, will
help us study how these features relate to binarity in a less biased
manner, in addition to increasing the expected success rate.

epoch photometry we have shown that
we can recover periods for four known binary CSPNe, and con-
ﬁrmed that four of the previously unknown variable sources have
light curves consistent with binarity. This lends weight to our hy-
pothesis that many of the variables that we have identiﬁed from
their mean photometry are indeed binaries.
Completeness and accuracy will improve with future

data releases, with more transits increasing the statistical signiﬁ-
cance of any observed excess variability. Improved photometric
processing and handling of non-single systems will reduce spu-
rious sources of photometric scatter, and ultimately epoch pho-
tometry will enable us to conﬁrm new binary candidates from
